Creative Electron CEOBill Cardoso      When San Diego-based Creative Electron announced this week that its TruView Parts Counter now uses AI, I wondered if it really  used AI or if the marketers had simply rebranded an existing feature by calling it AI. To find out, I spoke with Creative Electron CEO Dr. Bill Cardoso by telephone.    Cardoso, who holds a Ph.D. in electrical engineering, started by thanking me for questioning if his product uses AI. âI really didnât want to use âAIâ to describe our productâs new feature because I have an allergic reaction to marketing claims, but the marketers won,â he said. Cardoso went on to explain how the AI works.    The TruView Parts Counter is used by manufacturers to count the number of parts on a reel â first when the parts arrive, then as they are used so that the manufacturer can track costs. One reel can be used multiple times for supplying components to the same or different PCB designs. Unfortunately, people drop parts when loading and unloading reels, making counts inaccurate. It was even worse when trying to identify connectors because of their different shapes.    To solve the problem, the company turned to AI. Using AI, the system âlearnedâ to identify component shapes after being subjected to them over hundreds or even thousands of reels.
